column4: I urgently need all the stuff required to compile things for the kernel version 2.6.29 on an arm device, where can i find the kernel headers for that?
apt-get install build-essential, and you may have to explicitly install the headers package for your kernel version, use apt-cache search to locate those
well i tried searching for it on aptitude and it couldnt find anything with my kernel version, only 2.6.31 and upwards
are you using a stock kernel?
then the headers wont be packaged either, you'll have to symlink the headers in /usr/include
if you are using a custom kernel then you will not find the header files packaged for it, unless you run a custom version of a prepackaged kernel
thats why im asking if there was an ubuntu version running version 2.6.29, so i could just use those headers for it, do you happen to know which version used it?
9.04 shipped with .28 and karmic shipped with .31, so no
hm where could i get a set of headers from then?
they are in the kernel source package you build from
if all this is confusing to you perhaps consider switching to prepackaged kernels for you?
thats not possible for that device, ubuntu only runs inside a chroot environment

yeah you'll have to get the sourcepackage that build your kernel(oogle), and then either manually setup the headers via symlinking, or package the kernel (!compile) as debs and install the headers as deb.
or could i just throw all the sources into the folder of the program i want to compile every time i want to compile something? (the lazy but messy way)
well the build chain expects to find headers
